fol.115r
Belgia
1591 st
i
Ro
m
23 March To my L. Trea
s
Belgia: 1591: March:
May it please yo
r
good L. a letter from you of the 9
was delivered unto mee the 21 of this moneth: wherin yo
u
will mee from her
Ma
ty
to expostulate w
th
the
states
for
theyr slacknes in relieving the towne of
Ostend.
At sondry
times before both her Ma
ty
by her owne letters and also yo
r
L.
in
e name of her Hig
nes
hath required my endevours to
e
self same purpose. And for mine owne
te I do assure yo
r
L. there was never any matter that I moved so often
or so instantly urged as that of Ostend. But how
e states
stand affected, their letter to her Hig
nes
w
ch
they sent by
S
r
John Norreis
, and an oth
r
from my self,
writt
w
ch
was written to
yo
r
L. will c
r
tifie sufficiently. They are all of one
Jugement, that
e
Governo
r
hath no cause to presse her
Ma
ty
so far for any dout of
e ennemy. Nev
r
theles upon
this motion now againe, w
ch
I have made from her Ma
ty
they have yelded to
e sending thether of 2 companies of
their owne nation: upon condition
t
when they shalbee p
r
pared
to go into
e field, they may bee returned heer again. I have
also obtained that such provision of powder and corne, as
before they did but promise in generall termes, shalbee p
nt
ly
sent thether by order out of
Zeland.
Howbeit they do
flatly avoutch that
e publick magasin of
e towne, hath
bin alwaies by the countrey sufficiently stoared, but that it
hath bin consumed in privat uses, by those of
e garrison, w
th
out
mission from hence, & against
e coustome of
e Countrey.
Moreover to such effect as before they have written once
again, both into Zeland, & elsewhere, that good enquirie may
bee made to learne
e ennemyes
ceading
in those quarters of
Flanders:
to
e end they may ordain whatsoever shalbee
requesit. For as now they saie they know nothing of either
sieg or surprise or oth
r
enterprise toward
. And though the
Gouverno
r
have enformed her Ma
ty
of many occasions of
feare, yet neither hee him self did ever write so much to them
nor any one of their officers that sejowrne in
e garrison.
w
ch
are as vigilant as may bee in every such occasyon.
S
r
Edward Norreis is a gentleman of that merit, that every
man hath knowen, & to mee in
ticul
r
very friendly affected,
for w
ch
I may be thought, both very unkind & inconsyderate
to advertise any matter that is neither precisely w
th
in
e compas
of my charge, & may seeme in some sort to touch
e credit of
his actions. But forasmuch as my meaning being construed right
fol.115v
Belgia: 1591: March:
is syncere & friendly & my duty to her Ma
ty
must make mee sett
a
te all private respect
, & because yo
r
L. I knowe will
make no farder mention
en is nedefull of my
name, I will
signifie somwhat how it standeth at this present between S
r
Edward &
e states. It is a g
na
l order of
e contrey
w
ch
ev
r
y Gouverno
r
of any towne that belongeth to
e States
is strictly sworen to ob
s
ve,
t
they shall not medle more or
les w
th
e matters of contribu
o
n, of impost & accise, or of
any point,
t
shall
taine to
e civill pollicie of
e place.
Not onely thos that are Gouverno
r
deputed by
e states, but they
that have
e charge of
e cautionary townes are in
t
respect
restrained by a spetiall article of
e treaty. The case is
very evident, & there is no Gouverno
r
of
e Countrey that
doth seeke to be exemted. nevertheles S
r
Edward Norreys
doth usurp
t
authority, & being often required to take an ohter
course doth seem to heed yt so litell, as they have entered into
speech to remove him from thence. hee p
r
tendeth unto them, that
hee doth nothing of him self, but by order from home, & by
her Ma
tyes
direction, w
ch
doth very much amuse
e
Councell of st
ate
& doth foster in manie an old rooted Jalousye,
t
her Ma
ties
ministers
would bee maisters of their townes & bring theyr Country into
s
vitude as much as
e Spaniard: whose gouverment
ey abjured
for defence of their liberties. In effect I know theyr
humor so well, and I see they are so peremptory in all
theyr purposes as unles they bee obaied in their owne jurisdiction
they care not if the Towne should fall to
e Ennemy. and
this in truth is the chiefest occasyon,
t
they hearken so
unwillingly to any motion of
e Gouverno
r
. For otherwise they
know
e Importance of
e place as well as is possible.
and they saie they will tender yt as much as shalbee requesyt,
if they may bee respected as by all other gouvernours. Th
e
Gouverno
r
they Imagin to
s
ve his private tourne is an author to
her Ma
ty
of many wrong impressions, and devised alarmes,
making his desseing, to manege all thing
alone, & to conve
rt
the benefit of
e generall meanes to his private uses:
or
at least to be disposed as hee himself w
th
out them shal
l
think most expedient. I am alwaies earnest to
persuade
them otherwise, alleaging his want of experience in
the affaires
of these countreys, and other matter of excuse, as
I have also
written to himself, & wished him in any wise to w
th
stand these
beginning
, & to apply his course somewhat more to
e
nature of
fol.116r
Belgia: 1591: March
this gouverment. But because his aunswer hath bin,
that hee frameth all his doing
w
th
e notice of her
Hig
nes
, I have nothing to replie. For my self I
see not, nor I cannot conjecture, how her Ma
ties
service
may be bettered by it. But I am verie much afraid,
unles they have their willes, the end wilbee but trouble
& danger to
e place. the considera
o
n wherof and of
my duty to her Ma
ty
, & my confidence w
th
all
t
yo
r
L. will suppresse my name in this matter, doth enforce
mee to im
te this advertism
t
at length: Besides I
thought not im
tinent to give yo
r
L. to consider, the copie
of a l
re
w
ch
e Councel of late hath sent unto
e Gouverno
r
.
Two daies past I Rxd a l
re
of
e 22 of Febr
u
writen
at
Dresden
from
S
r
Horace Palavicine
: Hee moveth mee
th
r
in to help to sett forward a second contribution,
but I
not douting, but
e first was alredy heer accorded, & to
signifie unto him, how
e forces of that levie, might
bee best employed for
e benefit of these countreys.
For the matter of contribution
Mons
r
de Touraine
was
put in good hope at his beinge in
e Hage, that
e Provinces
would yeeld to 10000
li
st
l
. But they shall not finde
them now so forwarde as then they made acchount.
For unles it were
Holland,
w
ch
are well enough affected in
respect of their portion, the rest of
e Provinces wilbee
hardly brought to any thing. Of a second collection
there was never no speech, & I hold it in vaine to trust
upon it. For as it should appeare by S
r
Horaces
letter, hee supposeth that
e States wilbee drawen to
contribute great sommes in regard of
e
s
vice that
e
armie passing this waie may do to
e Countrey. Howbeyt
I do not finde that there is any opinion in these men
heer, that
e use of those forces can much advantage
theyr estate. For they saie in private conference, that if
the staie of the armie should bee long in thes quarters, it
would turne
e countrey to a great deale of detriment, and
the opportunity would bee lost of assisting
e
King:
as
one
e other side they can reape but litel benefit by a
littel tariance. All
e help that they expect is 3 or
4 daies
s
vice in
e assault of
Balduc,
&
e spoile in
theyr passage of
e ennemies countrey; moreover wh
r
as yt is
supposed both by Mons
r
de Touraine & S
r
Horace Palavicine
t
the States will joyne of their owne forces as well english as
fol.116v
To my L. T
re
r March 23 1590
Belgia 1591 March
others, to accompanie
e armie into Fraunce (for they spake to
mee to
t
effect when they were at
e Hage) I signified then
unto them, & still I am
swaded, that
any no
the states
will never yeeld that any nomber of their forces, shall go
farder from
e Provinces, then as they may finde a commodious
retrait. What I write unto yo
r
L. I will c
r
tifie S
r
Horace,
& of any thing besides, that I can any waie conjecture to
bee fit for his purpose. The Brute is much encreased, of
Parma
his resolution not to go into
France,
& because wee
are advertised, that 40 peeces of battery ar
vided at
Anwerpe
it is very much suspected,
t
hee will give some attempt
upon
Berghen,
or
Breda.
The want of paie among his
souldiers doth
cause
a great discontentm
t
in sundry of his garrisons,
as now wee have intelligence of 2 ensignes of hye Dutche
in
Grave
that are newly mutined, & by
e rest of that
garrison driven out of
e towne.
Verdugo
as yt seemeth hath
had some intelligence of
t
we have entended against
Deventer
&
Zutphen,
w
ch
he hath notified unto them, &
they therupon are very buisily occupied in
e fortification
of theyr townes,
& thus for this p
nt
I take my humble
leave. Hage March 23 1590./
